xVJjPthzeYQHBYK2mIwZZQ.text: Had Sunday breakfast here, not so good. Eggs Benedict had a tasteless, almost solid hollandaise that clearly wasn't fresh. The ham wasn't great either. The eggs were quite nicely cooked, though. My companion's croque monsieur was drowned in an artificial-tasting bechamel. Sort out your sauces, please! Given the quality, value for money on the food was non-existent. The worst thing, though, was that our waitress tried to keep the change - presumably as a tip - even though this establishment already applies a service charge. It was embarrassing to have to ask for it back (after a 20 minute wait).

J9fVYkrP_e-ACDnOpsjp0Q.text: Cote is great when you are in a hurry to get to the theatre or concert.  The pre-theatre is a good deal and a nice selection of dishes.  The food was very good with very fast service.  The prices are reasonable.

8YT4E1LeZMvEVyjN83rSow.text: I had dinner there with a couple of friends not long ago. They loved it. I was less impressed. Don't get me wrong the staff are very nice and helpful and I had a sole meunière which was delicious but the whole atmosphere is a bit much. Too French to be French if you know what I mean...

rgQW9RRDnp_kR2vSnozQBA.text: Decent food and value, but absolutely disgraceful service that they should be thoroughly ashamed of. We will not be going there again due to the service, which was so bad that it ruined an otherwise tasty meal. I went to the one at Hayes Galleria near London Bridge. The waiter who seated us was extremely friendly and courteous, but the waitress who took our orders and served us was extremely rude and grumpy and thoroughly let her colleagues and restaurant down. We had to wait 45 minutes in a nearly empty restaurant for our starters (soup), then a further 30 minutes for our mains. What was worse, once we gave in and asked where our mains had got to, the waiter went straight into the kitchen and brought them out instantaneously, so they had obviously been sitting around and no-one had bothered to bring them to us. The waitress was rude and grumpy, took one person's plates away when the other 3 of us had not finished eating, poured more wine to our designated driver without asking. When I asked for a certain main course, the waitress said bluntly none left, no apology, no friendliness, just a grumpy reply. As a slap in the face for me, I later saw that main being delivered to another table who had arrived and ordered after us. To add insult to injury, when we got our bill, they had added a huge service charge to it (£7.50 for a meal that came to less than £50). After such appalling service, this added insult to injury and we didn't know whether to laugh or cry at this cheek and we did not pay this. No complaints about the food, it was good, but the service is the worst I have ever experienced.

Sf99Odo_iE2lvLJ6y_9IHw.text: Went to Cote, Wardour street, on a Friday night with 2 friends. The service was efficient, friendly, with a sense of humour - even got a free liquor ;-) and the food was good. Had steak frites - really nice thin crispy chips and the rump steak wasn't tough at all. And it's worth saving space for the desserts!

AbKSV3YzBJEQo4VZIEJK0g.text: good food & drinks worth every penny

Q8x3EgHVFCgx0jduKKg7-w.text: Delicious food, great atmosphere and very reasonably priced for a good Soho restaurant. What more could you ask for?

QzDKI1TLReibcSFQhPZeIw.text: good low key place that we stopped in for a snack. hit the spot.

X8eK_X-vntB7k8MrIS2Vfg.text: I am not a big fan of beef, but steak frites from cóte melts in your mouth, can't be missed. Great value too and nice simple selection of wines

mzW8AUKcA0Eo7JM9IqZ-MQ.text: The lunchtime service was busier than I've seen before and therefore the staff were clearly overstretched, but when there, they were friendly, helpful and knowledgeable. The food was, as my previous three visits; classic, well cooked, and simply seasoned. My Steak Frites, was tender and slightly pink (as forewarned) with well seasoned crispy chips. They are Cafe Rouge, how it should have been done. At £10 for my main it was exactly what I ordered no less no more. If only they could now replace all the Cafe Rouge's in London...Great Staples 7/10

9CuaoBvoSrnn2m9bSbpDzg.text: This place is darling!  Very charming and the service was excellent from the host to the waiter.  Its extremely loud and you will likely have to shout to your dinner guest but its lively and the food was pretty darn good for the price.  I wouldnt recomment the steak frites however, its a little thin for my taste.  However scallops and pork belly was quite good.

o4xbymW1t7u25Vg88i8EcA.text: One of my favourite restaurants in Soho for a business lunch - not the most exciting food in London, but just very comfortable, excellent choice of dishes  fish, meat, poultry, good service, no fuss. Can be a bit noisy. Best to book in advance, but was able to get a table on the same day. Wanted a French restaurant where my business associate could find his favourite (steak tartare) and I could pick something that wouldn't interfere with the restrictive diet I'm on at the moment. Waiting staff allowed me to order the meat without the sauce and to choose the accompanying vegetables from a different main course. Portions are quite large  I couldn't finish mine. Ordered only non alcoholic drinks without receiving any black looks. Only small problem was that it took a bit too long to find someone to bring the bill.

4vNuGEpljcYayr6hXzhF6w.text: Fresh, non-pretentious French food in a comfortable environment. Known for its steak and frites for a reason - it never fails.

pUjdyOu7UPoNWyyX2kgJqw.text: Surprisingly affordable and delicious Niçoise food in the heart of Soho. Service is not the speediest, but I was not expecting such good food for the price. The atmosphere is quite nice as well.

FeG-nodMhW2mImyIN9GALw.text: Nobody does food like Cote. Fresh, hot, delectable and over the top delicious!! THANK YOU COTE!

Caz7v7Xi7RTFoW_-gJVA5A.text: My husband and I shared our favorite meal at Cote during our four nights in London.  Yes, we were tourists.  Sure, we don't know a thing.  But I can tell you our experience here was excellent.  We stopped in for dinner on a Sunday without a reservation.  It was around 8pm and the restaurant was fairly quiet (silly Americans... eating dinner so early) but by the time we left nearly every table was filled.  We were seated at a small, two person table and were greeted by an extremely friendly waiter.  I loved the whole feel of the restaurant.  Dark woods, dim lighting, candlelit tables, and large glass windows - excellent for people watching on busy Wardour Street.  Everything was polished and put together in a very modern but cozy way.  Big points for that.  Comforting décor goes a long way in my book.  It had been at least two hours since our last drink so we hastily ordered a bottle of Bordeaux.  Wine prices were very reasonable and while I can't remember the name of the Bordeaux, I do remember that it was tasty.  We started our meal with a freshly baked sourdough baguette and butter - when in Rome... or France, right?  The bread was definitely good, though a bit chewy around the edges.  Next, our warm Roquefort salads graced the table with their presence.  I'd never seen a salad put together so beautifully.  Each individual sliver of endive was filled  with walnuts, croutons, and warm, strong Roquefort dressing.  It was so gorgeous I was almost sad to eat it!  But eat it I did, and it was delicious.  We both decided to go traditional and ordered the steak frites with garlic butter for our entrées.  The steaks were fantastic.  Thinly cut, but still juicy and flavorful.  The garlic butter was a nice touch, but the steak was good enough stand on its own.  The frites were thinly cut as well, and crisp on the outside, soft in the middle - the perfect match to our steaks.  If I were the type to kiss my fingertips after a great meal, I would have done it at Cote.  On a side note, my husband took it upon himself to recreate this excellent steak frites experience at several restaurants in Paris, but sadly for him his favorite steak frites remain at Cote in London.  Who would've guessed?  While dessert sounded tempting we ended our meal with two café crèmes.  We enjoyed excellent service throughout our dinner.  It never felt rushed and we were left to linger over our coffee in peace.   Also worth mentioning - the restrooms at Cote were sparkly clean with eye catching design.  Quite a refreshing change from some of the rather scary toilets I'd experience while in London.  So with our stomachs full and our wallets a bit lighter we faced the rainy streets of London completely content, and promised ourselves that we will visit Cote again next time we cross the pond.

V1meS6Bxn-A5eMFqWpjH9w.text: Girlfriend and I headed to Cote after seeing Phantom of the Opera at Her Majesty's Theatre.WOW.Amazing place. The atmosphere is incredible for a date or a night out with some of your classier friends. (Make that one t-shirt wearing friend pop on a collar and come along too!)I don't remember the last time that I was treated so well in a restaurant. Everyone was incredibly friendly and very kind and patient. Our server (I wish I'd asked her name, as she is someone to be sought out if you're eating here... she's really small and has her hair cut pretty short. Big smile.)On to the meal!We enjoyed the Goats Cheese Tartine (Chargrilled sourdough bread with soft goats cheese, roasted baby artichokes and black olive tapenade), the Mushroom Crepes (Baked crépes with mushrooms, spinach and gruyère cheese - these were INSANELY delicious), and a lobster dish as our main course. Jessica assured me that it would just be a lobster tail or something because the price seemed so low compared to what it would be in America. When it came out it was a lobster chopped in half with all of the meat still inside the shell. SO weird!!! But she took charge and tore the meat out. It was delicious, though I did not really care for the process. After our main course we enjoyed a chocolate concoction that made Jessica close her eyes... it was so rich and delicious. For beverages I enjoyed a beer called Kasteel Cru which is brewed with champagne yeast. Easily one of the best beers I've ever had. I'll be looking for a case in Paris so I can ship it home and let you all try it. We also enjoyed a bottle of the Maison L`Aiglon Chardonnay 2009, Vin De Pays D'Oc (Melon and pineapple with subtle toasty oak) - which was a very, very delicious bottle of wine.Oh! The prices are very reasonable as well! GO GO GO!

LLd1zWJV0fH-uEhY4MahaQ.text: Now I had my reservations about this place. I don't like boards outside of restaurants (I am a portly chap and they get in my way) and I tend to grimace at lunch time 'meal deals' being so heavily promoted. However, I decided to venture in and give the place a go. And what a good decision that was! My dining buddy and myself were seated in good time and at a lovely table. Water and bread came so quickly that I felt it was summoned by god, however at no time did it come across that we were being rushed, despite the restaurant being to capacity. I ordered scallops to start with and we shared the most mouth wateringly sumptuous rib of beef. I get my fair share enjoyment out of life but I have to say this beef excited me to levels I only thought were possible with Tahitian swimsuit models. The scallops were not bad either and came with fantastically crispy bacon. All this was washed down with a gorgeous bottle of Pinot Noir and rounded off with a cheese board. A wonderful meal was had by my friend and I however, I did manage to walk straight into the ladies toiletsI either put this down to poor signage or excellent wine.

FClJGi0OblL1eaDceZhaKw.text: This place is solid.  Had a lovely lunch here.  The service was good and the food was tasty.  Great bread and olives to start, nice appetizers (asparagus soup, mussels, frise salad with bacon and poached egg) and nice mains....steak and frites, salmon, etc.  It was half empty on a sunny Sunday.  A great place for a nice leisurely casual but delicious and affordable lunch.

PYfjgZNJcphe5bqmz2K98Q.text: Excellent breakfast menu - all the eggy things with salmon and so forth, lovely strong coffee and welcoming service - with big picture window looking out onto the hustle and bustle of Wardour Street in the morning. You can probably get away with sub-£10 with a bit of care, too. Excellent - so much better than getting caught with an overpriced greasy hotel breakfast.

B1sohAN4L__NMtgIq3bAoA.text: I dined here on Friday 12 December for our staff Christmas party - my fourth visit to this restaurant. It's become one of my favourites - not as inexpensive as you'd expect for what's become a chain (Covent Garden, Soho Wimbledon), and in a very slightly higher class perhaps than Strada, though with a different and fairly rare offering; French food based on the southern style; pissaladière, described on the menu as a flatbread, is a Niçoise adaptation of pizza, (usually) without a cheese base and with caramelised onions, herbs, tomato or anchovies. You'll find a good tuna niçoise, provençale sauce with the (deliciously tender) chicken, mouth-watering pots au chocolat - just what you'd find if you were on the Côte. Steaks are magnificent and I've found to the continental taste. Order medium and it'll be arrive cooked at the well-done end; medium-rare is what an American might call bleu. So be careful what you wish for! Service is very good, and the atmosphere pleasant. Sit upstairs for a more relaxed vibe (the basement can be a bit airless) and in the right-hand room for more intimacy. Expect to pay around £50 for three courses with wine, if you're going to town on dinner. Which of course, you will be.

yUjZxUuxJ2ICVOhzKHAJ2g.text: I had lunch at Cote and really enjoyed it. This is a new French brasserie with a menu with lots of choice and very reasonable prices. The service was surprisingly good for such a restaurant. It has a bit the feel of a chain but it may be because it is so new. I had a poulet-frite and a tarte tatin, all good (maybe the chicken was a bit dry but overall ok for a £9 main course). Note that they offer complementary filtered water and come regularly to refill it and to check that all is going well. The deco is very well done, sort of modern French retro brasserie style, very elegant and clean. A great address in Soho and a good French restaurant full stop.

photos.caption: Photo of Cote - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Cote - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Cote - London, United Kingdom

lH0El_JJj8JVuXXfUWIB9Q.text: This small London chain offers classic French Bistro food at prices that would not knock your socks off. I went there with a friend for a birthday lunch, she had Risotto with broad and green beans, spinach and herbs (and what a lot of herbs!) whilst I had linguine with seafood, chilli and garlic. Both dishes were robust, filling and perfectly cooked. The pasta was al dente whilst the risotto wasn't 'gluey'. The seafood was fresh and perfectly cooked (soft rather than rubbery) whilst the risotto was packed with herbs and vegetables. My dining companion, not known for subtlety in the face of poor food or service was generous with her compliments, commenting with a hearty smack of the lips 'THAT was nice'. It was, and some. Cote have branches in Wimbledon and Richmond with plans to open in Covent Garden soon. On a sunny late September lunchtime, being here was not dis-similar to suddenly being in the Marais district of Paris on a late Summer's day. Ah, magical memories.

tdC8J7g3MW6ZN5cjmkijvg.text: came here for breaky this morning, and if im not mistaken this premises used to be an indian restaurant called 'Soho Spice' (i liked that place :() they've remodelled the interior to what resembles a chic 5star boutique hotel's breakfast room. They do breakfast lunch and dinner. i found it hilarious that a French restaurant would sell a full english breakky! haha! I had the smoked salmon with scrambled eggs. My dish was nice, well presented and overall above average. Service here was a bit slow considering there were only two other tables there at the time. notheless staff, highly attentive and gave a true five star performance.I would certainly return and from my brief experience have been convienced i need to return for dinner here.

MxKS-KMap9xfU0Z8TB683w.text: Well, had my day out in London yesterday and went to Cote in Soho having looked at Qype reviews on it, have it say it was really nice. I had the Mussels for starters, the steak frites for main and the most gorgeous Creme Brulee for dessert which was exceptional. It was just under £25 for the three courses. The only moan I can really have is that they brought us the Lunch menu, (we arrived at about 1.15), we chose from it then was told the menu was only available from 3pm to 7pm! Bit ridiculous since lunch is usually 12pm to maybe 2.30 however, to make up for it we got our first drinks free as an apology. I think if the company changed this policy for the timing of the lunchtime menu it would be quite perfect - they could of course just change the name of the menu!!!

yURLNxnyrpS2X5TqxqhGPA.text: Went there for New Years Eve, Very good meal, great value for money, friendly and attentive staff. A no brainer!

l_QxMghF3HcHL_GNHq-CkQ.text: Sunday morning, 11 AM, in August, and we could get the best window table right away. Really quiet, and that while my crepe & eggs & bacon were just great. Toast on the side comes with 3 jams, the OJ was a big glass full. I have no idea why it was so empty, this place was great! Does nobody brunch here?

KA0pTduj7dfinmMnxfhuOw.text: Great food but no cheap. I always think that if they don't have 6 snails the there not a true French bistro.  I ordered the grilled stake with galic butere and frise. I Thoght it could use a bit of salad. But overe all good

rANUsOLvzRkLZ_2fHuOrqQ.text: Cote is a perfect pre-theatre meal eaterie. It is located in a central Soho position and I rate it highly and after a number of visits over the past few years have never had a bad experience there and can only recommend it. They have a good range of food and good wine on offer but I really rate their 2 and 3 course deals which are good value, delicious with a good variety of dishes to try. The service is always good, polite, friendly and quick considering it is always busy but the staff seem to cope well with this, particularly if you say you're in a rush.Highly recommended.

8bbdo5ZLKagnUHxIDGsPeQ.text: We were having trouble finding somewhere to eat in Soho (midweek) that didn't have a huge queue so in the end we settled on Cote. It has a very simple menu and the food is decent but not outstanding. The staff are really nice and helpful. I wouldn't run back here if I had other options but at the same time it's a reliable choice if you don't!

qb1_NWPO6yxheoA27AV_TQ.text: Nice prix-fixe for dinner before or after a show. Loved the bread, nice and fresh. The Steak Frite is good, not as good as Le Relais de L'entrecôte in Paris, but will do when you're in London.

P9BO4PIPkifgyODnpgeB9Q.text: It's rare to wander around Soho on a cold winter night and stumble into a restaurant that is not only good, but not bad value. That's Cote. The only negative thing is that this is one of a chain of 10 restaurants, but the formula is polished and well-done.Our service was nicely handled and our server attentive and professional and very French (no coffee?) I ordered cider because I just felt like it and got a cloudy bottle of a boutique brand that didn't exactly go well with my fish pie, but I didn't care! The fish pie was filled with salmon, haddock and prawns and topped with cheesy mashed potatoes piped on in a lattice pattern. The waiter also offered up complimentary after-dinner liquor which was a nice touch to thank customers. I recommend Cote if you have 30 quid to spend on a leisurely dinner, but I'm sure you can spend less also.

_3ntUbQjL70CmW9bCeroqg.text: NOT the place for brunch... def not the place to get decent eggs benedict!the hot cocoa is really mediocre, and not even mixed well,the eggs benedict which you pay £8 for, come in two mildly toasted english muffins.The eggs whites were actually runny and not coagulated, but clearly one cannot find this little fact out until they CUT through the "hollandaise" which was like a spreadablly THICK mayonaise blanket covering the buns.The plates are presented VERY poorly... with not even one single garnish of any sort. VERY disappointing... especially on mother's day. I have sworn Cote off.

YbIo7ju5EHFZUmeZ051Ajw.text: Tesco value meat tastes better. Good wine selection though :) Ordered boeuf bourguignon, was tougher that leather.

bM-r7Mez3cGylmDfI3leiQ.text: Poor food for the price they charge. We had a duck dish which was low to average, a tasteless salad with chicken which any supermarket can prepare better and a glass of wine and paid 50 euros...

lGntMWSlX6oEODTHIZhD9A.text: I have passed Cote a couple of times in Wardour Street and always wanted to come in - the menu (think French inexpensive brasserie) looks so inviting, and the restaurant so cosy. Finally I got my opportunity to eat here, and am pleased to say that it fully lived up to my expectations.The restaurant, which is large and on two floors- still manages to retain a feel of intimacy because it is divided up by wood panelled walls. We were seated in a booth (every restaurant should have booths), and our friendly waitress gave us plenty of help in deciding what to get. My friend decided on the reasonably priced 2 course menu for £9.95 (making it 3 courses is only £2.00 more expensive) and had a warm beetroot and goats cheese salad to start, and spatchcock for a main. I had a Roquefort salad with endive followed by a wild mushroom and spinach crepe, washed down with a couple of Kir Royals. We both raved about our dishes, so much so that we didn't even want to share!The desserts looked equally as tempting, but all we could manage was to share a dish of berries with heated white chocolate sauce poured over. The meal came to £20.00 a head, including service, which we were more than happy with. A top choice.

photos.caption: Photo of Cote - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Cote - London, United Kingdom

deu-IufdwYDNzor9SoSMNA.text: Marvelously cozy, yet simultaneously sophisticated place to dine.  Maybe it's the glow of the appealing light fixtures, or the low noise level, or the very palpable French brasseriness of it, but the interior just oozes with warmth.  Even though my visit here was a random walk-in affair... I would definitely put Cote on my list for a special and slightly more dressed-up occasion - pre-theatre or Easter brunch or the like.The food was immaculately presented (even the pomme frites look regal wrapped in a flourish of white gauzy paper), mouthwateringly savoury, and just-right in portion (nothing to excess... perhaps even leaving you wanting just a smidge more - which I think is how all distinguished dining should be).  My friend and I started with the olives (always a must!), flatbread with cheese and thyme (this was richer and more decadent than I expected - but in a good way), and the Roquefort and endive salad (fresh and succulent, but the Roquefort dressing was runny and tasteless to the extent of being practically pointless...).  For our mains, I had the cheese crepes and my friend had one of their steaks - we found them to be respectively delectable and deeply satisfying... I don't think it gets much better than melted Gruyere for a vegetarian, nor a well-aged steak for a carnivore!   As an aside, one of the other reviewers mentioned a set-price menu of two to three courses... this didn't seem to be an option when we were there - everything was a la carte... and you definitely couldn't get a starter AND a main for anything close to £9.95... but still well-worth the price!

photos.caption: Photo of Cote - London, United Kingdom. Cote Interior
Photo of Cote - London, United Kingdom. Endive Salad

B6FVkKDxvd95MCU1XMgenQ.text: Nicely done food. Mouth-watering salmon, tender duck confit. Good wine list and not horrendously pricey, especially in Soho!  Good service.

42XukG_UN06jK_gLxX4_YQ.text: This restaurant deserves better ratings! Very good food and service. Very reasonable price too.

GOrEk-rCIXQk2KL_HQ4rRA.text: I visited the Soho branch of Cote last Thursday, on a lovely balmy summers evening, with a largish crowd of around 10. We arrived pretty much on time for once and we were swiftly shown to our table in the basement area. Even though it was only 7pm the restaurant was pretty full and there was a nice buzzy atmosphere. Bottles of the house white and red were quickly provided while we were giving the classic French bistro style menu, which has plenty of choices to suit most tastes, the once over. I think it's always a bit of challenge for staff when dealing with a large group but we were handled beautifully all night, and without too much stress we had soon been cagouled into making our choices - no mean feat with this crowd. I was sitting with my old pal Broggy and we decided to split our starters, so we shared a goat's cheese tartine with sourdough bread and a crab mayonnaise. Both were nicely presented, well-seasoned, very tasty and a very decent size portion. I then moved onto a main of the 10oz rib eye steak which came with a dainty portion of frites on the side; I teamed this up with some béarnaise sauce which was an extra and added a couple of pounds to the bill. My steak came medium rare as I had requested, this was well-seasoned and had a good char. It was a very tasty piece of the meat and a pleasure to eat, which is more than I can say for some steaks I have had the misfortune to order in other chain restaurants in central London. Our group ordered a pretty wide variety of dishes from the menu and everyone seemed pretty pleased with their meal. By this point I was a bit too stuffed for dessert but I did try a spoonful of Broggy's crème brulee which was perfectly ok but nothing out of the ordinary. Throughout the evening all our dishes were served at the same time, came to the table hot, were cooked as ordered and came without too much of a wait; in my experience this kind of service is something of a rarity when you are dining with a large party in central London. The wine list is good if you are keeping an eye on your wallet with house wine under £15 and plenty to choice from under £20. As far as chain restaurants go this is my favourite in London by a country mile and it does what it says on the tin: "simple, freshly prepared French food at value for money prices". We left sometime around 10.30 with the restaurant packed and folk queuing up for a table as we stumbled out into the crowded Soho streets in fine spirits.

9havwi9cTxJtpPIqcxRtIQ.text: Orange juice wasn't fresh at all. Steak and frites : meat was tough as leather, salmon was nice though! Overall: not to recommend! 2 stars for service and quantity

O78cIws-X5QEjl7oXvtIew.text: I really like Cote. I've been in three different branches by now, including this one twice, and the food is consistently good, the staff unfailingly excellent and the place is invariably buzzing - hardly surprising considering the quality of the product. We were in London for the weekend and misplaced the teenager for the night so repaired to Cote for dinner and a natter. We started with cocktails, Kir for her and G&T for me. My only complaint of the night was that the G&T seemed rather lacking in G. Moving on swiftly, my calamari starter was really good and we shared both this and the olives and divine bread my other half ordered. She followed with a tuna salad which she said was excellent. I took her word for it as tuna and I have an uneasy relationship of which the less said the better. It looked good. The Beef Bourgignon was almost as good as my own specialty dish at home... Sniff ! OK then - it was better. Drat. We accompanied this excellent repast with a smooth bottle of Fleurie which went down a treat although it was so moreish we polished it off half way through the main course. We passed on both dessert and coffee and the bill, including 12.5% 'optional' service charge came to an aesthetically pleasing £88.88. Excellent meal, well presented and efficiently served. We will definitely be back.

vanHhZzH658GKO-qQBXduA.text: Fantastic bread and lentil starter were musts. Cauliflower soup and steak were meh. Mushroom risotto was undercooked yet still managed to be delicious. Great service. Went next door for dessert. Do before 7 for good special.

TagSkOJKA66P50FldlSG1Q.text: When I want to go somewhere that's consistently going to be nice and I know the menu, I'll go here.The corn-fed roast chicken is amazing (though I'm not sold on the garlic butter), and is served with a cup of thin-cut fries and salad. Very nice salads as well, and beautiful French bread. I've never tried the steak, but friends of mine say the steak frites is usually a little cold, but the rib-eye and the sirloin is very good. More impressive however is the breakfasts. Always top notch and very well priced, particularly considering that it's right in the heart of Soho.In short, it's nothing stunning, but it's always tasty and well-priced. Watch you don't get stung on the drinks though, they can very expensive very quickly.

R8e09whXI8RSHaPZ-iS8ZQ.text: Cote is a French bistro on Berwick Street. It is an attractive building noticeable due to the glass frontage that extends around the restaurant. It is a decent sized restaurant with quite a few tables inside. In summer they open the windows which give the place a nice inside / outside feel.I often go for brunch and it is a perfectly place for it. The service is quick and amiable. The Eggs Benedict is very well done and the coffee is decent. There is a pleasant unobtrusive ambience about the place which makes it good for conversation within small groups. Furthermore the prices are reasonable.Cote is a good place that achieves the feel it seems to be aiming for.

photos.caption: Photo of Cote - London, United Kingdom. From Website
Photo of Cote - London, United Kingdom. From Website
Photo of Cote - London, United Kingdom

EXI6nRY43UQK7KQ3kMnebg.text: Happened upon this place as my first two choices were booked up. I understand it's a small chain but it really did not feel that way at all. Had a perfectly lovely dinner on my own and felt very comfortable.I had a tuna nicoise...and it was a perfect size, with an interesting addition to the norm - red and yellow peppers in addition to olives, haricot verts, small potato slices and lettuce.  The dressing was really nice - light but flavorful.The bread was Delicious.  Had a  side of frites and they were good but not great. In european style they were a little undercooked for my liking.  And the portion was just right - in a goldilocks kind of way.Had a nice french chardonnay, amply poured.My only gripe is that the service was average at best.  I sat for at least ten minutes before being addressed.  Once i had my meal I never saw my server.  In fact the hostess took my plates and brought me the bill.  It seems like this restaurant is perennially busy, so  I would think they'd have servers who can handle  a number of tables simultaneously.Overall a good experience but far from stellar

zcDJHbILCanASCzcsNGQiQ.text: We found cote on a Saturday night after waiting in line for another restaurant and it was a lucky thing we did. The french decor is very pleasing and professional looking, and the service is very prompt and polite. A fun note is that all of the water brought to the table are in stoneware bottles that say the water has been filtered through blah blah...the bottles are super cool. Just my thing.Anyway, my friends and I all had steak, ranging from medium rare (yours truly...i like them red!) to well done. All were amazing and done appropriately. The appetizers we oredered took a while to arrive, but they were quite good. THe mussels looked amazing and I'm sad that I ordered pate instead.Overall, it was a great experience. Our entire meal of steak and appetizers was under £20 due to a special being offered. Highly recommend if wanting to impress your parents or a date!

3yJms5pEjPyqsABZktVidA.text: The perfectly competent and attentive service and well-prepared and presented continental-style breakfasts pleases me immensely.  This is about as close as you'll get to a brunch in London, and I can definitely get behind that.  I love brunch.I had a pot of tea (which was just sort of meh), and my sister had a mimosa.  These drinks were followed by the 'small' portions of Eggs Benedict and Eggs Florentine.  I appreciated the option to get just one muffin and poached egg instead of the standard two, because not only was this cheaper but it also left more room for eating later.  You see, as I sat eating my beautiful hollandaise (which was a little on the sweet side at first but tasted excellent once seasoned with rock salt), I was already thinking about where I might take my visiting sister for lunch.  Gluttony: that's how I do holidays.

QiB1KQzVT6dlLzrROdgT6A.text: Beautiful brasserie in the heart of Soho. BF and I came in looking for a breakfast spot and were not disappointed. Amazing and attentive service. The food was excellent too! I had the full vegetarian English and he had the traditional. Really scrumptious veg sausage, perfectly poached eggs, and a full pot of tea and fresh OJ for under 10. Really lovely inside and we will keep this place in mind for our next trip to London and recommend to our friends.

oecji_rc96r9vUE6VipmmA.text: Phenomenal English breakfast. Eggs were perfectly cooked and the sausage was delicious. Lots of food and great service for a very reasonable price.

cUAkAmuvOhLHJ8AWQUyCwQ.text: I'm shocked this place doesn't have a better average rating since it's one of my go-to's in Soho.  I've been three or four times for dinner and each time has been a great experience.  It's an upscale-ish restaurant that's centrally located, the service is friendly, and the prices are super reasonable.  I used to try to bring my friends to other restaurants in the area, but they would complain that they wouldn't be able to afford rent if they ordered a main course, so that was a problem, and Cote solved it.  Try the duck or the seabass!Food: 4/5Value: 5/5Service: 4/5Atmosphere: 4/5

8Tx-ozL9eC0Za-Jwyd1mdg.text: Tasty French dinner with a great 2 course special for 12.50 pounds. Had the duck pate and seabass, both were delicious.

MwFJQFf_TfplNUiGjq4UdA.text: We had a great brunch here on our vacation to London. The service was fast and we both enjoyed our food. I had the vegetarian breakfast which was huge and a great mix of items. It is probably not the cutest place in London but a nice atmosphere.

GMyng7hakn4-ztspWZelDQ.text: Have eaten here many times. Always a good meal. You need to avoid it during theatre time otherwise it could get busy and staff less attentive. You can't go wrong with most items on the menu. Worth a try.

C_Cq_am5-37F5NIOhCkoWQ.text: I've been to this Côte as well as the one at St. Christopher's Place a few times each. Same menus, of course, so I am going to write one review. Try to change my mind on that. You can't! By the time you read this, I have already moved on. There's nothing you can do about it!I almost always order the same thing. Steak Tartare, and a Tuna Nicoise salad. The Tartare has a little bit too much shallot for my liking, but it's decent. It's kind of got that ketchup taste going on, which is pretty impressive for London, considering there is a perpetual ketchup shortage in the city and the country as a whole. An intentional ketchup shortage, I ought to add. It's not an actual shortage. They just don't want it.The Nicoise is very good, too. Nothing fancy there. It's just good.That's all I can write about that, as my flight from London to Los Angeles is now about to take off. It's been delayed for a while. Damned snow.

zBtMLNt3LNcqsXzBwpKzfQ.text: So I'm in London for work this week and after a very long and intense day, had the urge to do something fun. Luckily my amazing colleagues - E and R - were in a similar mindset and off we trotted towards Soho.We stumbled across Côte quite by accident, but at a tenner for Steak Frites we thought "why not!"I had the pork belly which was absolutely beautiful, melt in the mouth & cooked to perfection. The sauce which came with the caramelises apples was almost a dichotomy to the rest of the dish, so bitter that i wasn't entirely sure I liked it but the mash was excellent and complimented that well.E and R both opted for steak, R going for the 10oz rib eye with the garlic butter sauce and E for the steak frites. Both agreed it was the best steak they had ever had.All in, for this plus my cheeky kir royale we were under £45. In the middle of Soho at 8.30pm on a Saturday night that is a pretty amazing deal. I'd definitely go again.

DJfZuPuiOASb9fGyH1q5wA.text: My boyfriend and I had a mostly lovely meal here on the last night of our vacation in the UK. We walked in without a reservation and had no problem being seated. The ambiance was low key and pleasant and the food was very tasty. We started with some bread and the chicken liver pate which was absolutely delectable. The pork belly was enjoyable with a crispy melt-in-your-mouth skin and came with a side of savory whipped chive potatoes. What I wasn't crazy about was the sauce that came with the dish - the thyme was overwhelming and I found myself pushing the sauce to the side which left the pork a little dry.My boyfriend enjoyed his steak and chips and was full enough to pass on dessert. I decided to order the creme brulee which was disappointing. It was extremely cold and the bruleed sugar on top was burnt. What's worse is that it took FOREVER to come out... we almost decided to cancel and pay the bill by the time it finally came.Service was very friendly but slow... although I have to wonder if that's just my American expectations being too high because every establishment we ate at in the UK had equally slow service without apology.I'd probably come back here for the prix fixe lunch but I don't think I'd pay the regular a la carte prices again.

8shKSF6B4Vn_r0GSHRRYLA.text: Went here for my cousin's birthday. Had the pre-theatre menu. Delicious all-round. The ratatouille for starter was tasty and fresh.I had the steak with fries and garlic herb butter. I prefer a bit more sauce than just butter so they gave me a little ramekin with pepper sauce in it. The chicken with potato puree looked great and tasted delicious.When desert came round they kindly brought out a candle and sang the little guy happy birthday. Friendly efficient service & very good value.

I1FUOCdfN4K6v6yZvAty1w.text: Average. Not a great meal. Not a terrible one. I had the French Onion Soup for an appetizer and it was a bit heavy on the thyme. It also lacked some of the depth of onion flavour that tends to come with these. My fellow diners had the Roquefort Salads and all enjoyed them. Dinner was cassoulet. I haven't ever had it before and I enjoyed it but I found the duck a bit dry. Other meals were steak frites which were apparently good and my friends raved about the lamb. We didn't have dessert. The service was excellent. Overall I would go back but wasn't blown away.

_pNAGg9gDUXzIgEbCwBopg.text: Underwhelming in the light of day.I've been to Côte several times for dinner.  I've enjoyed it.  I've recommended it to friends.  I've had some pretty good food there for the price I've paid. And it's had a decent ambience for somewhere chainy: low lights reflecting off mirrors and polished wood, tables not too cramped, casual but darkly elegant in that French brasserie kind of way.But now I think I know why they turn the lights down so low at night. I went there for breakfast on a Saturday morning and I can't say it was anything like the evening experience. For one thing, the place was a bit... well, grubby. Not filthy as such, but certainly not polished, and looking a bit tired, drab, not particularly clean and in need of some attention.  Also, the fruit flies that were buzzing round in an attempt to share our breakfast brought on an entirely different ambience to what I was expecting.The food was OK.  Really just OK (French breakfast good, my dining partner didn't enjoy the crepe).  But it didn't feel OK when I felt a little embarrassed having brought somewhere here on the promise that it was really nice. The service was attentive.This review almost scraped its way to 3 stars, based on my past good experiences and the possibility that they (or the cleaners) were having an off-day.  But I really need to base this on my last experience. So there's massive room for improvement, Côte.

BXsY5kzOt9FXwZj64Cy0wQ.text: Pretty brutal as far as French brasseries go...could possibly have served me the worst steak frites I've ever eaten!  As Run DMC would say that beef was TOUGHER THAN LEATHER! ecx.images-amazon.com/im…

MBJGlsAD4MmLoOBkTTQFkg.text: Came here last minute last night and got the two courses for £13 deal which is really good for Soho! I had the leek and potato soup that was so yummy I basically inhaled it. I then had the steak which was OK with a tasty green side salad!

OjQIiTRU6YiqExqg_W9jnA.text: Dined here multiple times with both work and friends and it has yet to loose a star. The service is always friendly and prompt, the food is always well portioned and well cooked. You cant beat the pre theatre menu for value and quality. Highly suggest the potted beef although im not sure its on the menu any more. Its always my fall back option as I know it will always deliver

Vbzv9S8ptcBTNgF14vVcOw.text: We were wandering around Soho and looking for a place to eat on a Tuesday evening. Nobody in our group was feeling necessarily decisive, and we took turns suggesting and dismissing food ideas. Oh, and also, we were drunk. Someone in the group had to pee, so we stopped in a pub and had some more beer. I asked the bartender to suggest a place within stumbling distance that was good, and he pointed us towards Côte. When we arrived, I thought it would be mediocre, mass-prepared type of food. Like a TGI Friday's of French food or something. The meal was a lot better than I thought it would be. All of our dishes were delicious and well-prepared, the calamari was some of the best I've ever had, the mushroom dishes (namely the poulet grille and mushroom feuillete) were divine. For the price and in that part of town, finding a good food spot that you can get into without booking a table is a nice bonus. It was not ZOMG the best meal ever, but it was solidly delicious and we all felt comfortable and happy. The end.

hCvogSGAyrlYQinvyrQ_QA.text: Cote rates as a perfectly acceptable and perfectly predictable restaurant for business travelers and tourists.  I had the veal escalope, which was pretty much as the waiter advertised: a giant slab of pounded and breaded veal with no vegetables or starch.  It was good, as veal always is.  The wine paired great, too.  But I don't remember much else about the experience other than a distracted server, and the inoffensive space and decor.

LKjFIx63gl6lN79FnEb93g.text: Chicken livers, benedict, boeuf bourguignon and steak frites! Really good food and value for the money. The boeuf bourguignon came out steaming hot and the meat was so tender and flavorful. They also had a 3 course pre-fixe option that was very reasonable.

wJwyWtB0oTaQ3gNd-3jZnA.text: My all-time favourite! I highly recommend the risotto and chicken fillet. Considering the quality of the food, the price is amazing. It's a nice place to drop in with a friend for a decent meal, but it does get quite packed during dinner so better make a reservation if you don't want to queue for two hours!

1F_W-ZEcB5NWPfGChZL_QQ.text: Singlehandedly THE WORST meal EVER. This was a trifecta brunch day...Standing in the rain @ the Breakfast Club hungover and STARVING was not going to happen. Not in a line that was going to take more than 20mins to move.Princi was packed and far too chaotic, and standing sipping coffee trying to narrow our choices, someone, spied Cote. And for reasons that elude my bourbon soaked brain we followed our stomachs and the promise of food in a quiet environment.So we got our peace and quiet...as we were seated in the farthest back room away from the people watching windows and other jovial brunch diners.And sure, we got what could pass as food...if you're blind drunk and scrambling in the fridge at 3am to put together a toasty aka: croque monsieur - but it was so sad and lonely (garnish? salad? help me! i need something here on this plate), and pathetic and quite honestly, unappetizing to look at (greying pool of mushroom sauce oozing out of my crepe), that we took 3 collective bites... and hustled for the cheque.Comedic really...as our waitress, when responding to her inquiry as to how our food was: "not great. In fact, pretty disappointing, tasteless and inedible", smiled, nodded and said yes. Not the response one hopes for.And so, we soon found ourselves, standing on the sidewalk, in the rain, making a mad dash back to the Breakfast Club.

hLv5NduTAG6t8ez-8as1ow.text: We came here for an early dinner before heading out for some nighttime fun.They jammed us in next to an older couple and they even talked about being cramped in the corner too.The scene here was for the theater crowd so it helps to come at off hours or make a reservation. Our food was mediocre at best. I ended up getting the steak frites that was not that that flavorful. It was a flattened out steak (never seen steak frites served this way) and not very good. By contrast, my friend got the tuna nicoise which was actually quite good, plentiful, and fresh.I'd normally give this place three stars but the cute blonde hostess told us about some different spots to hit up for dining and night life which turned out to be some good tips.

esNZCWYtb3V30s9fX1T9IA.text: I came here on a Friday early evening, maybe around 5p; the restaurant wasn't busy at all.  I didn't make a reservation because considering I was a party of 1 and I wanted to go before dinnertime, I took my chances. ;) I ordered the moules frites (mussels with fries) and the portion was massive!  They not only provide a discard dish but also a small dish of lemon water for you to wash your fingers from the mussels. The mussels were absolutely delicious - they were so tender, soft, and fresh.  I rarely have mussels that soft; it was amazing!  The broth that the mussels were cooked in was buttery and savory (but not salty!!). The fries were thin-cut, crispy on the outside, soft on the inside. Their olives appetizer was also delicious.  It was actually a mix of olives, pickles, and other unidentifiable pickled items (hah).  Overall, I would definitely recommend this spot for dinner!

4cTMGen5zR4rxrf1alGf4A.text: I stumbled on this place when i qas looking for french cuisine after shopping. I made the right choice eating here. They were offering a 3-course deal which i decided to try and it was amazing!! I started off with fried calamari which was quite fresh and delicious! I had the pork belly with al the veggies and scalloped potatoes.  For dessert i had the flan (can remember the actual name) i was so good. Its quite easy to find if you are shopping on oxford circus. The servers were nice and recommended all the meals i chose and i enjoyed them. Lots of buses around the rea,street psrking available as well.

photos.caption: Photo of Cote - London, United Kingdom. Starter: fried calamari
Photo of Cote - London, United Kingdom. Menu
Photo of Cote - London, United Kingdom. Dinner!

2IpjR6vm_fBAbK_TiqeeDg.text: For a chain I think the food is of a good standard, reliable and interesting. Have always found the staff here friendly too.

d8z9_lJ90uvDh2hEVawOZA.text: Me and my friends were both missing Paris and French cuisine. We were definitely not disappointed!The onion soup was just as good as the one I had in Paris a few months ago, and everything else is just as good!We went for the set two-course meal (£16.95 each) plus some little extras (an onion soup to share, two sides, crème brûlée, a glass of whine) and let me tell you, the taste was well worth the price (around £60 in total)! The staff was also very friendly, and kept us our table despite being almost 30 mins late because of bad weather.Would totally recommend this to anyone who's looking for a nice meal out with a great atmosphere (Soho is one of the best neighbourhoods in London), especially if you're trying to alleviate a bit of French nostalgia.

photos.caption: Photo of Cote - London, United Kingdom. Baked spinach and mushroom crepe (delicious!! Sooo cheesy!), potato gratin on the left, creamy spinach on the right and duck at the back.

9-eRcRUGOJuIxScMf1gy1A.text: It was not bad, but not amazing either. It a nice meal with some details that could be better. But generally a good experience with nice service.

2lrLVe3DvyaavL0qIkA2Ug.text: Fun to see the staff working well together - the hostess, too, is efficient and didn't make a fuss when I asked to be moved to a place that wasn't in a stuffy, dark corner.

photos.caption: Photo of Cote - London, United Kingdom. Fish and chips.
Photo of Cote - London, United Kingdom. Fish and chips.
Photo of Cote - London, United Kingdom

Irppi0-B_Lsd_V14fV9ACA.text: We love this Côte, the staff are always great and service is good. The food is good. We love the neighbourhood and it's great for people watching in the window seats.

photos.caption: Photo of Cote - London, United Kingdom

jvVUt76w39CoSBwNaYQIaQ.text: Tried to go to Breakfast Club but saw the line there and aborted! Walked by Cote and loved that it was completely open to the street. On impulse, went in. Notes:+ Amazing atmosphere. Soft jazz, windows make inside seating part of the street. Great people watching  (though on a Sunday, seems more limited foot traffic)+ Beautiful heavy bottle for water. Never seen this before. Will upload picture. Absolutely loved it.+ Very prompt service.+ Food was excellent. I mean English breakfast is the same everywhere, but there was something about every part of it that tasted fresh and vibrant.+ Cloudy apple juice. Interesting. Refreshing.- Coffee sour but possible that was intended.Mostly the vibe. I could have stayed there for hours. I ended up shazaming a bunch of tracks because I just hoped to slip into the same vibe after returning home by playing a bunch of them.

photos.caption: Photo of Cote - London, United Kingdom. Beautiful vibe starting with this amazing openness to the outside...
Photo of Cote - London, United Kingdom. Loved this heavy water bottle. Perhaps psychological but I felt it kept the water ice cold the entire time I lingered there.

PFnp-zdKBFFb_QMYP7nlZA.text: I got the Fish Parmentier and it was pretty good.  The cheese and mashed potatoes confuses me at first because I didn't know it wasn't the fish.  The price is a good price for most of the food and the service is average.  The thing that is the best about this place is the location since it is next to the river and you can see the Tower Bridge.

AqT9YbPpR7I4ftZhSl-WhA.text: September 20 is waiter Ryan's birthday.  Drop in and wish him a happy birthday, everyone.  We only had a small coffee and snack, but it was delicious.

fYHzKGnRWu2J_PpX94IukQ.text: Wonderful French restaurant in Soho! The menu has a great variety of delicious appetizers/entrees/desserts. The food was delicious! My mom and I both ordered a chicken dish with mushroom sauce and it came with potato gratin. The restaurant has a great atmosphere. I came here for lunch on Sunday, and the restaurant was full of people; which was great because who wants to eat in an empty restaurant! The restaurant staff let my mom and I stay at our table for a long time after we were done eating. Love this restaurant!

photos.caption: Photo of Cote - London, United Kingdom. Delicious Poulet Grille 11.50

6sqgLQS2xf3t6wkqnL_EJQ.text: Friendly and efficient staff, great breakfast, and very good prices.I had the full English breakfast deal: 10 quid for sausage, bacon, tomato, mushrooms, eggs, toast, juice and coffee (Le Formule on the menu).  It was excellent - I usually don't like eggs (had them scrambled) but these  were fresh and exceptionally well prepared.  Good quality bacon and sausage as well, and a jug of drinking water is provided free  too - a nice touch.  For downtown London and the quality of the breakfast, this place is a real deal. The staff was welcoming and very good at their job.  I recommend this place highly.  My go-to full breakfast place in London.

Uf2TpKjfzDzDVgHtdgQY_g.text: I came here to avoid the lines for the near Breakfast Club and thought it's just breakfast so how can this be so bad.  I got what I expected - solid breakfast meal, attentive wait staff and reasonable price.I give it a three because it isn't the hip spot and the ambience is just OK.But I would recommend this place if you are near by and don't want to wait in a 60 minute line.

photos.caption: Photo of Cote - London, United Kingdom. Eggs benedict, or and coffee for under 10 bp

GnxKAvtcmKRjNcGncU-riw.text: Fantastic food at surprisingly good prices. Excellent, friendly service. Real French cooking, in the heart of London. Value: one starter, three mains, two desserts, three teas-only 77 pounds ($108). Every dish was great!

zAVO3R3uhuO8yfjgfyA5Ig.text: Great french fare at a ridiculous price. This place is right out the back door of the Soho Hotel so I've eaten here twice during my current visit. Breakfast - Full English (2 eggs, 3 bacon rashers, sausage, tomatoes, mushrooms w/ toast £7.75 w/ juice & coffee drink (called Formula £9.95). Bargain pricing but very high quality & my 2 eggs were cooked exactly as order, poached hard/not runny. My skinny flat white coffee was also perfect, hot & flavorful. I love coffee & drink a ton, so I did have a second one which was also delish. Lunch - Chicken & walnut salad. The chicken was moist & flavorful. My only complaint was the dressing was a little heavy, but I usually ask for it on the side & forgot. Free wifi - ask for the codeFree filtered water - served in a cute bottle. The ambiance was authentic french brasserie & the servers were very friendly - ironically which I don't think is very french :-)

photos.caption: Photo of Cote - London, United Kingdom. Complimentary filtered water. Bread & olives are not complimentary but worth the small charge.
Photo of Cote - London, United Kingdom. Chicken & walnut salad

6JqcXdXWkM8_jm9nXEY6zg.text: Friendly staff, good service and delicious food. We were looked after having waited some time for our meal, with the staff going above and beyond expectations. Big thumbs up!

kP_XWygNgIcc963-1R-MLA.text: Had a lovely dinner here!Was walking through Soho looking for somewhere to eat.  Ended up at Cote...  Initially had my reservations bt these were soon dispelled. The food and service was stunning and the location is perfect!  Will visit again!

photos.caption: Photo of Cote - London, United Kingdom

9K3EDIojHlEmiQX1raSpAg.text: Very friendly and quick service. The chargrilled steak was very good and cut very easily. Very generous if the restaurant to give complimentary water in Coté's own earthenware bottles. The French Onion soup was served below the desired temperature but they attended to our request right away. Location is excellent and they welcomed us with our five year old son and even gave him a kids menu (though he also opted for the steak).

photos.caption: Photo of Cote - London, United Kingdom. Loved their complimentary water in the earthenware bottles.
Photo of Cote - London, United Kingdom. Waiting for the pink steak and the Cod for The Rocky!

ENAxQy9LV5loanqydAf0wg.text: Half a chicken with mushroom sauce and creamed spinach (instead of regular fries). Great value and good sized portion. The service was excellent tonight but the restaurant were also rather quiet at 1830. Been here before and will be back.

photos.caption: Photo of Cote - London, United Kingdom. Chicken, creamed spinach and mushroom sauce.
